notesStmt.note: BBWW performed in Baltimore, Maryland, September 30-October 1, 1895. Theo Heckert was a railroad contractor who had a "grading outfit" used in construction of the canal [See Patrick, p19]. Horace C. Alger (1857-1906) was a banker from Sheridan, Wyoming, mayor of Sheridan in 1889, and a candidate for Governor of Wyoming in 1898. Cody, Beck, and Alger were responsible for developing the Shoshone Irrigation Company. George Bleistein (1861-1918), Buffalo, New York, owned the Courier Printing Company and provided printing for BBWW. Bleistein was also a partner and director in the Shoshone Irrigation Company. Daniel O'Day (~1846-1906) was vice-president of the National Transit Company and one of the five leaders of Standard Oil Company. O'Day's greatest achievement was engineering the transfer of the oil-carrying trade from the Empire Transportation Company to the Erie Railroad. He was instrumental in construction of the first oil pipeline in the state of New York in 1873 and in building the first pipelines from the oilfields in to New York City; O'Day served as president and/or director of many oil-related companies including National Transit Company, Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company, Atlantic Coast Realty Company, Buffalo General Electric Company, Buffalo Natural Gas Company, the National Fuel Gas Company, Federal Trust of Newark, People's Bank of Buffalo, Seaboard National Bank, and New York Produce Exchange Safe Deposit and Storage. Daniel O'Day was a friend of George Bleistein and a close personal friend of John D. Rockefeller. On p3 of this letter Cody asks about naming "streets" or "tracts" after both Northern and Southern Generals of the United States army. In letter dated September 25, 1895, he refers to naming streets. The initial plats of the town of Cody show that streets were named after generals; the main street through Cody is Sheridan Avenue, after General Philip Sheridan. Nathan "Nate" Salsbury (1846-1902) was an actor and head of the Troubadours, a traveling stock company which would eventually tour Europe and the United States. After Cody met Salsbury, the "Wild West" show venture would begin, and in 1884 Salsbury would become a partner as well as Vice-President and Manager of BBWW until his death on December 24, 1902. William E. Hymer (~1853-1933) was one of the early members of the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company. "Prest Perkins" probably refers to Charles E. Perkins (1840-1907), businessman and president of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad. [The abbreviation for president during this era was "Pres't;" however, Cody rarely used apostrophes.] Colonel Allison Nailor (1836-1908?) was a friend of Cody's and was with him on his trip to the Grand Canyon in 1892. Henry Guy Carleton (1813-1901), the oldest son of Major General James H. Carleton, became a noted American humorist, journalist, author, playwright, and an amateur inventor of the 19th century. John M. Burke (d1917), a scout in the Indian wars, was WFC's publicity manager for the stage productions and the Wild West exhibitions.

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Baltimore, Maryland, September 30-October 1, 1895; there was no performance on Sunday, September 29, 1895.
Note 2: Sulphur Creek is a natural streambed located west of Cody, Wyoming, flowing north toward the Shoshone River along the south side of Cedar Mountain.

Note 3: Daniel O'Day (c.1846-1906) was the vice-president of the National Transit Company and one of the five principals of Standard Oil Company. O'Day's greatest achievement may have been engineering the transfer of the oil-carrying trade from the Empire Transportation Company to the Erie Railroad. O'Day was instrumental in laying the first oil pipeline in the state of New York in 1873, building the first pipelines from the oilfields to New York City. O'Day acted as president and/or director of many budding banks and oil-related companies. Mr. O'Day was a close personal friend of John D. Rockefeller and George Bleistein.

Note 4: Cody asks about naming "streets" or "tracts" after both Union and Confederate Generals. In a previous letter dated September 25, 1895, Cody also refers to naming streets in the first planned town site, and the initial plats of the town of Cody in that original location show the streets named for generals. In the town site's later and current location, the main street of Sheridan Avenue, named for General Philip Sheridan, is the only street honoring a general; the principal east-west streets were and still are named for founders of the town.

Nope 5: "Nailor" is likely Colonel Allison Nailor, Jr. (1836-1908), from Washington, D.C., who was a friend of Cody's and with him on Cody's trip to the Grand Canyon in 1892. Nailor and others were expected to join Cody on the hunt that he was planning for December 1895.

Note 6: "Prest Perkins" would likely have been Charles Elliott Perkins (1840-1907), then president of the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy. His son is referred to as "Young Perkins Son." In Cody's time, the term "president" was often written as "prest."

Note 7: Henry Guy Carleton (1813-1901), the oldest son of Major General James H. Carleton, became a noted American humorist, journalist, author, playwright, and an amateur inventor of the 19th century.
Note 8: The hunt Cody was planning for December that year.
